snippet: The Haqqani offshoot of the Taliban displayed discipline and sophistication in the latest attacks, which has Western officials concerned at their failure to intercept any intelligence chatter.
abstract: Western officials, surprised by the scale and sophistication of synchronized attacks in Afghanistan, see it as a troubling step in the evolution of the Haqqani Taliban network from a crime mob to a militant force; episode raises concerns about whether the network has the ability to mount such audacious assaults repeatedly, rather than just once every several months, and whether the Afghan government can blunt such plots after 2014, the deadline for Western troop withdrawal.

byline.original: By ERIC SCHMITT and ALISSA J. RUBIN
byline.contributor: Eric Schmitt reported from Washington, and Alissa J. Rubin from Kabul, Afghanistan. Declan Walsh contributed reporting from Islamabad, Pakistan.

lead_paragraph: The Haqqani offshoot of the Taliban displayed discipline and sophistication in the latest attacks, which has Western officials concerned at their failure to intercept any intelligence chatter.
